title-group.article-title: Effect of ionic products of dicalcium silicate coating on osteoblast differentiation and collagen production via TGF-β1 pathway

article-meta.aff: 1Orthopaedic Department, The Central Hospital of Huzhou, Huzhou, Zhejiang 313000, PR China
2Orthopaedic Department, The First Affiliated Hospital of Soochow University, Suzhou, Jiangsu 215006, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Junying Sun, Orthopaedic Department, The First Affiliated Hospital of Soochow University, Suzhou, Jiangsu 215006, PR China. Email: junyingsunsuzhou@126.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this work, the medium containing ionic products of dicalcium silicates (Ca2SiO4) for culturing MG63 cells was prepared by immersing a titanium alloy plate with the plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coatings in DMEM solution. The effect of the ionic products on cellular differentiation, collagen production, and local growth factors (prostaglandin E2 [PGE2] and transforming growth factor-β [TGF-β1]) of osteoblast-like MG63 cells were investigated. The normal DMEM was also used to culture MG63 cells as the control group. Differentiation of cell was evaluated by detecting alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity and osteocalcin (OC) synthesis as well as their gene expression. Collagen production was analyzed by Sircol assay. The levels of PGE2 and TGF-β1 in culture medium were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The gene expressions of TGF-β receptors (TGF-β RI and TGF-β RII) were also measured by real-time PCR technology. MG63 cells cultured in DMEM containing ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating showed enhanced differentiation and increased collagen production. The results obtained from ELISA showed that the levels of PGE2 and TGF-β1 in experimental group were higher than that in control. The gene expression of TGF-β receptors was upregulated, indicating that more TGF-β1 bonded to their receptors which produce more effects on the osteoblastic activity, leading to enhanced differentiation and synthetic activity of osteoblast. It is concluded that ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating may enhance cellular differentiation and collagen production by influencing TGF-β1 pathway.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bioactive glasses without phosphate were thought to be the more suitable materials for bioactive scaffold due to their beneficial effect on osteoblast differentiation and local growth factors secretion when compared to bioglass (BG) containing phosphate.1–3 Dicalcium silicate (Ca2SiO4) consists of calcium, silicon, and oxygen, which is similar to phosphate-free bioglass. Our previous works showed that plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating could induce the formation of hydroxyapatite (HA) when soaked in simulated body fluid (SBF) for 2 days.4–6 In addition, plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating exhibited higher bonding strength to Ti alloys than plasma sprayed HA coating.4,7 Human osteogenetic cells also adhered and differentiated well on the coating surface due to its good biological properties.8 Although the good bioactivity and biocompatibility of dicalcium silicates coating were confirmed, its interaction with osteoblast, in particular its effects on the phenotype and function of human osteoblasts, were not previously explored.

Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) family is most abundant in bone matrix compared with other tissues. It is synthesized by osteoblast, stored in its latent form, released from the bone matrix, and activated in the bone microenvironment.9 Members of this family include the TGF-βs, activins, bone morphogenetic proteins (BMP), and other related factors. TGF-β1 is considered the prototype of this large family of cytokines and an important growth factor for bone formation.10 TGF-β1 synthesis enhances proliferation and activity of osteoblast and initiates a cascade of events that regulate osteoblast differentiation and extracellular matrix deposition.9,11

Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is considered an important local factor that modulates bone metabolism through its effect on osteoblasts and osteoclasts.12 PGE2 has been shown to activate osteoclastogenesis13 and increase production of interleukin-6,14 which can further enhance osteoclastogenesis. In contrast, PGE2 also has been shown to have bone-forming activity. It enhances osteoblast differentiation and proliferation.15,16 Treatment of male, female, and ovariectomized mice with PGE2 increases bone mass in vivo.17 When given locally or systemically, PGE2 can stimulate bone formation and prevent bone loss.18,19 It has been demonstrated that PGE2 can either stimulate or inhibit cellular growth and differentiation of osteoblastic cells depending on PGE2 concentration.20,21 PGE2 with low concentrations has an anabolic effect on bone mass.22 At high concentrations, PGE2 is catabolic and associated with bone resorption.23

Several studies reported that the interaction between osteoblast and biomaterial could induce the production of cytokines, chemokines, and prostaglandins such as PGE2 and TGF-β1, in turn, they could regulate cell proliferation and differentiation in either autocrine or paracrine manner.3,24–26 Plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating was proved to have good biological properties. Therefore, it is possible that besides the direct effects of ionic products from Ca2SiO4 coating on osteoblasts, there is a paracrine regulation of prostaglandins and growth factors, which contribute to bone formation by alteration of osteoblast functions. MG63 cells were frequently used to evaluate cell differentiation and cell activity in response to biomaterials because this cell line exhibits many osteoblastic traits that are characteristic of bone-forming cells. In addition, it was demonstrated that this kind of osteoblastic cell could synthesize TGF-β1 and PGE2.27 In this work, we investigated the effect of the ionic products of plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating on osteoblast-specific gene expression and collagen production of human osteoblast-like cells MG63 as well as PGE2 and TGF-β1 secretion. In addition, the gene expressions of TGF-β receptors responding to ionic products of plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating were also detected.

sec.title: Preparation of the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating
sec.p: Dicalcium silicate powders with typical size of 5–30 µm were synthesized in the laboratory of Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. An atmosphere plasma spray (APS) system (Sulzer Metco, Switzerland) was applied to fabricate Ca2SiO4 coatings on Ti-6Al-4 V substrate with dimensions of 10 mm × 10 mm × 2 mm. The spray parameters were as follows: argon (40 slpm) and hydrogen (12 slpm) were used as primary and auxiliary plasma forming gases, respectively. The feeding rate of powders was about 20 g/min using argon (3 slpm) as a carrying gas. The plasma arc current and voltage were 600 A and 73 V, respectively. The spraying distance was 90 mm.4

After ultrasonically washed in acetone and rinsed in deionized water, specimens were soaked in the DMEM medium (Gibco-BRL, NY, USA) at 37°C for 72 h (10 coupons per 200 mL DMEM) without stirring, then specimens were removed and the medium was collected. The medium was named Ca2SiO4-DMEM in following description. The normal DMEM was used as the control medium. The concentration of silicon (Si), calcium (Ca), and phosphorus (P) in the medium was measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis. The Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control medium were then supplemented, respectively, with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mmol l-glutamine (Sigma), and antibiotics (100 U/mL penicillin G, 100 µg/mL streptomycin sulfate). The medium was sterilized by filtering with 0.02 µm millipore filter after the pH value was adjusted to 7.4.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: Human osteoblast-like cell line (MG63), derived from a human osteosarcoma, was obtained from the American Type Culture Collection. Cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mmol l-glutamine (Sigma), and antibiotics (100 U/mL penicillin G, 100 µg/mL streptomycin sulfate; Gibco BRL) in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 and 95% air at 37°C. Until confluency, cells were passaged at a 1:3 split ratio following trypsinization with 0.05% (w/v) trypsin and 0.02% (w/v) tetrasodium ethylenediaminetetra acetic acid (EDTA). All experiments were performed using cells on second passage. A phase contrast microscope (OLYMPUS, Japan) was used to observe morphological changes.

sec.title: Alkaline phosphatase activity
sec.p: MG63 cells were seeded into 6-wells culture plates at 5 × 104 cells/well in DMEM with 10% FBS and allowed to attach for 24 h. Then the culture solutions were changed into serum-free medium. After that, cells were cultured in the normal DMEM as control, or in the conditioned DMEM containing ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2. The cell culture mediums were collected after the cells were cultured for 1, 3, 7, and 14 days. Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity was tested as previously described.28 Cell supernatant was immediately analyzed using a commercial kit (ALP, JianChen biosystem, NanJing, China). Testing procedure was performed according to manufactures’ instruction.

sec.title: Collagen production
sec.p: The collagen production of osteoblast was analyzed by Sircol assay following the protocol of Tullberg in the fixed cells.29 The Sircol collagen assay is a quantitative dye-binding method designed for the quantitative analysis of collagen released into cell culture medium by mammalian cells. This method is based on the selective binding property of the Sirius Red dye to the [Gly-X-y] tripeptide end sequence of mammalian collagen. The solubilized collagen was evaluated by optical density analysis at 595 nm. The amount of collagen was calculated using a standard curve representing the relationship between collagen concentration and optical density.

sec.title: Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real time-PCR)
sec.p: MG63 cells were dispensed into 6-wells culture plate at 5 × 104 cells per well and incubated in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and normal DMEM, respectively, at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 for 1, 3, 7, and 14 days. Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen 1 mL per 1 × 106 cells). First strand complementary DNA (cDNA) was synthesized from 2 µg of total RNA in each sample using an Invitrogen Superscript First-strand Synthesis system, and then was amplified to generate products corresponding to mRNA encoding human gene products. Real-time PCR was carried out using SybrGreen qPCR SuperMix (Applied Biosystems, USA) for assessing the expression of ALP, osteocalcin (OC), TGF-β1 RI, and TGF-β1 RII, the house keeping gene β-actin was used as the internal control. An MJ thermocycler (MJ DNA Engine OPTICON 2, USA) was used for 50 cycles of PCR according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

Human sequence-specific oligonucleotide primers, designed on the basis of published sequences, are shown as follows: ALP (forward, CCT CCT CGG AAG ACA CTC TGA CC, reverse, CGC CTG GTA GTT GTT GTG AGC ATA G), OC (forward, CCT CAC ACT CCT CGC CCT ATT GG, reverse, GCT CAC ACA CCT CCC TCC TGG), TGF-β RI (forward, ATG GGC TTA GTA TTC TGG GAA ATT GC, reverse, AGA ATG ACG AGA ACA TAA CAC TAG AGA C), TGF-β RII (forward, TCC TGT TGA CTG AGT TGC GAT AAT G, reverse, GGT AGC AGT AGA AGA TGA TGA TGA CAG), β-actin (forward, AGC GAG CAT CCC CCA AAG TT, reverse, GGG CAC GAA GGC TCA TCA TT).

The total volume of 25 µL amplification mixture with an SYBR PCR master per well was performed for 50 cycles for ALP, OC, TGF-β RI and TGF-β RII primer pairs, and β-actin. After an initial step at 95°C for 5 min to activate the polymerase, each cycle consisted of 20 s of denaturation at 95°C, 20 s of annealing at 58°C, and 20 s of extension at 72°C. This was followed by an additional extension step at 72°C for 5 min. To show that there were no false-positive results, PCR reactions were carried out on reaction mixtures to which no cDNA was added. ΔCT calculates the differences between target CT value and the control for each sample: ΔCT = CT (target) – CT (control). The comparative expression level (fold change) was obtained by transforming the logarithmic values to absolute values using 2−ΔCT.

sec.title: Cytokine detection
sec.p: Cultures were maintained under the same conditions as described above. Aliquots of the supernatant were dispensed in Eppendorf tubes for storage at –80°C and assayed for OC (RD Systems, MN, USA), TGF-β1 (RD Systems, MN, USA), and PGE2 (Cayman chemical Co. MI, USA) using commercially available enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) kits. Testing procedure was performed according to manufactures’ instruction.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All results were expressed as mean ± standard deviation (M ± SD) and analyzed by Microsoft Excel software using the paired-sample t-test. p < 0.05 was accepted as statistically significant.

sec.title: Ion concentration in culture medium
sec.p: The concentration of Si, Ca, and P in the Ca2SiO4-DMEM and normal DMEM were analyzed by ICP-OES. The Si concentration in Ca2SiO4-DMEM increased about 19 times compared with that in normal DMEM (0.075 ± 0.008 mM vs. 0.004 ± 0.002 mM, p < 0.05). Whereas the concentrations of Ca and P decreased slightly in Ca2SiO4-DMEM (Ca: 1.553 ± 0.209 mM vs. 1.711 ± 0.168 mM, p: 0.853 ± 0.237 mM vs. 1.236 ± 0.10 1 mM, p > 0.05).

sec.title: Morphological observation
sec.p: Morphological changes of MG63 in both groups were observed by a phase contrast microscope.

On day 3, MG63 cells in experimental group were spindle-shaped in appearance and grown to near confluent state (Figure 1(A)), while the presence of intercellular space was found in control group (Figure 1(B)). No pronounced morphological difference of MG63 cells were found in both groups on day 7 (Figure 1(C) and (D)). Very interestingly, some random nodule-like accumulation could be observed in cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM on day 14 (Figure 1(E)), which most likely represents the centre of nodule formation; this could not be found in the control group (Figure 1(F)). Figure 1.
Morphological observation of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control: MG63 cells in experimental group (A) and intercellular space (arrow) in control group on day 3 (B). Pictures (C) and (D) show cell morphology on day 7. Nodule-like accumulations (arrows) in cells exist in Ca2SiO4-DMEM (E) on day 14 and in DMEM (F). (Bar = 50 µm).

sec.title: Synthetic activity
sec.p:
The ALP activity of MG63 cells in Ca2SiO4 -DMEM increased steadily and was higher than that in normal DMEM at all time points, the significant difference appeared only on days 7 and 14 (p < 0.05), as shown in Figure 2(A). The OC synthesis of MG63 cells (Figure 2(B)) showed no significant difference between two groups on days 1, 3, and 7, but the OC synthesis was promoted significantly in Ca2SiO4-DMEM (p < 0.05) at 14 days. The change of type I collagen production (Figure 3) was similar to ALP activity shown in Figure 2(A). MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM showed a higher level than that in control group at all experimental periods, especially on days 7 and 14 (p < 0.05). Figure 2.
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity and osteocalcin (OC) synthesis of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control: (A) ALP activity, (B) OC synthesis (C2S: Ca2SiO4-DMEM, control: normal DMEM, * shows significance at p < 0.05).
Figure 3.
Collagen type I synthesis of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control (C2S: Ca2SiO4-DMEM, control: normal DMEM, * shows significance at p < 0.05).

sec.title: Local growth factors
sec.p:
In order to evaluate the influence of ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating on the production of local growth factors in MG63 cells, the concentrations of TGF-β1 and PGE2 in culture medium were detected using ELISA. Comparing with the normal DMEM group, the TGF-β1 released into the Ca2SiO4-DMEM increased significantly on days 1 and 3 (251 ± 28.7 vs. 156 ± 38 pg/mL and 271 ± 21.5 vs. 174 ± 16 pg/mL, respectively, p < 0.05), as shown in Figure 4(A). Interestingly, the concentration of TGF-β1 in Ca2SiO4-DMEM dropped down to 71 ± 6.5 pg/mL after culturing MG63 cells for 7 days, significantly lower than that in control group (192 ± 17 pg/mL; p < 05). Whereas no significant differences were found in both culture media on day 14. Figure 4.
Local factors of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control detected using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (A) transforming growth factor-β1 (TGF-β1) levels, (B) prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) levels (C2S: Ca2SiO4-DMEM, control: normal DMEM, * shows significance at p < 0.05).

The concentration of PGE2 in Ca2SiO4-DMEM decreased gradually when the MG63 cells were cultured from days 1 to 7, and then increased on day 14 (Figure 4(B)). At all time points, there was no significant difference between the Ca2SiO4-DMEM group and the normal DMEM group; however, the concentrations of PGE2 in Ca2SiO4-DMEM showed slightly higher level.

sec.title: Gene expression
sec.p:
The transcriptional levels of ALP, OC, TGF-β1 RI, and TGF-β1 RII were measured using real-time PCR. The results demonstrated that the ALP transcription of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM was upregulated steadily from 1 to 14 days and reached the highest level on day 14, as shown in Figure 5(A). The transcriptional level of ALP was higher than that in control group at all experimental periods, especially on days 7 and 14 (p < 0.05). The OC transcription of MG63 cell cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM was not obviously upregulated on days 1 and 3, but showed higher level than that in normal DMEM on days 7 and 14, especially on day 14 (p < 0.05; Figure 5(B)). Figure 5.
Transcriptional level of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and osteocalcin (OC) of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control: (A) ALP transcription, (B) OC transcription (C2S: Ca2SiO4-DMEM, control: normal DMEM, * shows significance at p < 0.05).

The gene expressions of TGF-β receptors type I and II were shown in Figure 6. Comparing with the control groups, TGF-β RI transcriptional levels of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM were promoted on days 3 and 7, and showed a significant increase on day 7 (p < 0.05), then decreased on day 14, as shown in Figure 6(A). The TGF-β RII transcription levels of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM was slightly higher than that in control group (Figure 6(B)). Figure 6.
Transforming growth factor (TGF)-β1 RI (A) and TGF-β1 RII (B) transcriptional level of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM and control (C2S: Ca2SiO4-DMEM, control: normal DMEM, * shows significance at p < 0.05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In order to mimic the reaction when the coating was implanted into body, the plasma sprayed Ca2SiO4 coating was immersed in DMEM for 72 h to prepare conditioned DMEM for culturing osteoblast. After the immersion of Ca2SiO4 coating, the concentrations of Ca and P in DMEM decreased slightly, while the concentration of Si increased significantly. The result confirmed that silicon was released rapidly from coating immersed in culture medium, while the concentrations of phosphorus and calcium in culture medium decreased due to the precipitation of HA on the coating surface.3–5

An important step of bone formation is the synthesis and deposition of collagen type I, which constitutes 90% of the total organic extracellular matrix in mature bone, and is produced in large quantities by osteoblasts.30 In this study, the production of collagen secreted by MG63 cells was promoted at all experimental periods in response to ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating, significantly on days 7 and 14 (120% and 150% to control, respectively). Comparing the ion concentration of Ca2SiO4-DMEM with that in normal DMEM, we found that only Si concentration increases significantly. The aqueous Si was proved to enhance the production of collagen type I.2,31,32 Supplementation of orthosilicic acid in cell culture could increase collagen type I synthesis and gene expression in human osteoblasts.33 Our result also confirmed that the increased Si in culture medium induced the synthesis of collagen type I. It is likely to result from the hydroxylation of praline which is a critical step in collagen type I synthesis. The synthesis of collagen type need to be catalyzed by prolyl hydroxylase, and optimal activity of prolyl hydroxylase depends on the adequate concentrations of Si.34 However, the precise mechanism that the Si released from Ca2SiO4 coating regulate the synthesis of collagen type I should be further investigated.

The ALP activity is one of the most common markers of osteogenesis and is assumed to reflect the degree of osteogenic differentiation. It peaks after a certain time, declines again, and is followed by mineralization. The OC is a later marker of osteoblast differentiation. The results obtained from this study showed that not only ALP activity and OC synthesis but also their gene expression were promoted significantly when MG63 cells were cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM, indicating that the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating had potential to enhance osteoblast differentiation. This result is in agreement with previous reports that the ionic products of bioactive glass, specially Si, could enhance osteoblast differentiation.3,35,36

Silicon, an early regulator of cell response, is known to enhance proliferation, accelerate differentiation, promote matrix synthesis, and enhance bone formation.35,37 However, whether ionic products of bioglass or Si ion have a direct effect on osteoblast differentiation and collagen production and the corresponding mechanism are still unclear.38 Increasing studies demonstrated that the bioactive glass or their ionic products could stimulate osteoblasts secreting some local factors (e.g. TGF-β1, PGE2), which are important autocrine/paracrine regulatory factors involved in osteogenic processes that influence and regulate all aspects of osteoblast.3,24–26 This could contribute to the influence of ionic products of biomaterial on cell behaviors. TGF-β1, irrespective of the cell differentiation stage, modulates cell proliferation and its in vitro effect is an important regulatory step in controlling osteoblast proliferation and differentiation.9 In general, it has been suggested that TGF-β1 enhances the proliferation and early differentiation of osteoblasts, which is characterized by a high rate of collagen synthesis but impairs their terminal differentiation based on osteocalcin synthesis and mineralization of bone matrix.39 PGE2 is known to be potent activators of bone remodeling and has been reported as having both anabolic and catabolic effects on bone.12 PGE2 is a potent stimulator of osteoclastic bone resorption and osteoblastic bone formation.19

Results obtained from this work showed that TGF-β1 level of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM increased significantly on days 1 and 3 compared with that in normal DMEM, and its PGE2 level was also higher than that in control group over experimental periods, indicating the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating had direct positive effect on TGF-β1 and PGE2 synthesis. Keeting et al.40 reported that Zeolite A, a silicon-containing compound, stimulated TGF-β1 production in human osteoblast-like cells. The bioglass composed of CaO-SiO2 increased also the synthesis of TGF-β1 and PGE2 in MG63 cells.3 It was reported that TGF-β1 could significantly upregulate the collagen type I gene expression and synthesis.27 Enhanced differentiation of osteoblast precursors, promoted proliferation of osteoblasts, and increased collagen synthesis were found in the presence of TGF-β1 in vitro.41,42 Therefore, it is possible that the enhanced production of collagen and differentiation of MG63 cells in Ca2SiO4-DMEM, at least in part, contribute to the increased synthesis of TGF-β1.

However, the increased release of TGF-β1 in culture medium does not mean more osteoblasts differentiation and extracellular matrix production.20 Previous studies showed that most of the TGF-β1 synthesized by osteoblasts was in latent form which needs to be activated to produce its effect on osteoblasts by binding to its receptors, the type I and the type II TGF-β receptor (TGF-β RI and TGF-β RII).20,43 The binding of TGF-β1 to TGF-β RII stimulates this receptor to form a complex with TGF-β RI. The TGF-β RI phosphorylates and propagates the signal to downstream substrates and to make the effect of TGF-β1 on the cell by producing cytokines that are required for matrix synthesis and mineralization.43 Although many studies demonstrated that biomaterial or their ionic products could stimulate TGF-β1 synthesis, to our knowledge, the TGF-β RI and TGF-β RII gene expression in response to biomaterials in vitro was not reported. The presence or binding capacity of TGF-β receptors may affect the final response of the cell to the production of TGF-β and alter specific aspects of osteoblast function.44,45 Increasing expression of TGF-β receptors would permit more TGF-β1 binding to its receptor, in particular to TGF-β RI, which may make an effect on the osteoblastic activity leading to enhanced differentiation and synthetic activity, at last more bone deposition. On the other hand, if the expression of TGF-β receptors was not stimulated, large part of the released TGF-β1 remained in extracellular media, and more unbound TGF-β1 would be available to promote osteoclast recruitment and differentiation.46 It is thought to be the real reason that number of studies lead to conflicting reports about the biphasic effects of TGF-β1 on bone formation.42,47

In the present study, the transcriptional level of TGF-β RII of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4- DMEM were higher than that in normal DMEM at all time points, the transcriptional level of TGF-β RI of MG63 cell cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM significantly increased on day 7. Simultaneously, TGF-β1 level of MG63 cell cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM decreased obviously at day 7. Since the final concentration of TGF-β1 presented in the culture medium may depend on the amount of TGF-β1 bonding to TGF-β receptors,45,48 it is possible that the significantly low concentration of TGF-β1 in Ca2SiO4-DMEM on day 7 does not result from the reduction of MG63 cell synthesis but more free TGF-β1 bonding to the upregulated TGF-β receptors. Therefore, we suggested that the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating not only enhanced osteoblasts synthesizing TGF-β1 but also increased TGF-β receptors gene expression, which stimulates a higher binding of TGF-β1 to its receptors and then leads to significantly low concentration of TGF-β1 in the culture medium.

Only TGF-β1 binding to its receptors in osteoblast could produce its effect on osteoblast. From this study, we found clearly that after TGF-β1 binding to its receptors on day 7, ALP activity and OC synthesis, their gene expressions as well as collagen production were enhanced significantly. These findings are in agreement with previous reports24,25,41,42 that the presence of TGF-β1 in vitro could enhance differentiation of osteoblasts and increase collagen synthesis.

In the present study, PGE2 levels of MG63 cells cultured in Ca2SiO4-DMEM remained higher than that in normal DMEM, while ALP activity and OC synthesis in Ca2SiO4-DMEM were obviously enhanced when compared with that in normal DMEM. These findings confirmed the fact that the differentiation of osteoblast was positively correlated with the concentration of PGE2.49 Some studies20,21 showed that the PGE2 affected bone biology in a dose-dependent manner, also by affecting the TGF-β1 pathway. Lower concentration of PGE2 (from 10−8 to 10−5M) can produce a higher effect on the osteoblast, which significantly increases TGF-β1 synthesis and the expression of TGF-β RI, and so, permits more TGF-β1 binding to its receptors. This may produce a positive effect on the osteoblast differentiation and synthetic activity, which leads to more bone deposition. On the other hand, higher concentration of PGE2 (10−3 M) does not stimulate TGF-β RI gene expression, which results in that most of the released TGF-β1 free in the extracellular media, and more unbound TGF-β1 promote osteoclast recruitment and differentiation.46 In the present study, PGE2 concentration in all culture model was very low (10−8 M), indicating more influence on osteoblast differentiation by increasing TGF-β1 synthesis and TGF-β RI gene expression.

Therefore, the results obtained in this work support the idea that the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating regulate osteoblast differentiation and collagen production by affecting the TGF-β1 pathway. However, it must be considered that other growth factors, such as bone morphogenetic proteins, NO, and other TGF-β isoforms, may have response to ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating and cooperate/antagonize osteoblast functions. It seemed that the OC synthesis in this work was not modulated by TGF-β1 because it inhibited terminal differentiation of osteoblast by inhibiting OC synthesis.39 The reason for this might be that the later stage of osteoblast differentiation was regulated by other growth factors.21 Further investigations are necessary to give a better understanding for the mechanism of Ca2SiO4 coating on the bone biology.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present study demonstrated that the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating in culture medium may result in promoted differentiation and collagen production in MG63 cells. PGE2 and TGF-β1 synthesis of MG63 cells were also enhanced responding to ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating. Importantly, promoted TGF-β1 receptors gene expression was detected, indicating more TGF-β1 bind to the receptors, and so, enhance differentiation and collagen production of the osteoblasts. Therefore, it is possible that the ionic products of Ca2SiO4 coating influence the osteoblast behavior, in part by modulating the TGF-β1 pathway in the osteoblasts.

ack.p: This work was jointly supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China 30973041, Medical Science and Technique Foundation of Zhejiang Province 2009B153, Huzhou Science and Technology R&D Fund under grant 2009YS04 and 2010GS01
